Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students successfully completing high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. Particular emphasis is placed on transforming STEM education through innovative recruitment and retention strategies and experiences in support of groups historically underrepresented (URM) in STEM disciplines: African-Americans, Alaskan Natives, American Indians, Hispanic Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders.

Oklahoma State University (OSU), lead institution for the Oklahoma Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (OK-LSAMP), will double the recruitment and retention numbers of URM students in STEM fields over the five years of the project. The activities will strengthen scholarly participation in research and international experiences preparing students for global success. Activities are dedicated to building the skills and collegial relationships scholars will need to pursue successful careers in research, teaching, government, and the private sector. As scholars progress through the programs, including the associated Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) activities, they will be provided opportunities to develop collaborative leadership skills by working with peers and senior researchers, performing primary research for presentations at national and international conferences and publishing research papers with a multicultural perspective.

The STEM activities will result in increased numbers of a wide range of minority groups in the STEM workforce, not only in the United States but globally. The Alliance will provide an important national model for promoting the success of all minorities including Native Americans. Results from this research will be disseminated widely to inform understanding of how to encourage and support minority STEM education. Building on well-established relationships with local, state, and tribal nation authorities, OK-LSAMP will expand its impact into all diverse communities. OK-LSAMP institutional members include OSU, the University of Oklahoma (OU), the University of Tulsa (TU); Langston University (LU), an Historically Black College or University (HBCU); East Central University (ECU), Northeastern State University (NSU), University of Central Oklahoma UCO), Northwestern Oklahoma State University (NWOSU),Southeastern Oklahoma State University (SEOSU), Southwestern Oklahoma State University (SWOSU), and Cameron University (CU).

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Oklahoma Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (OK-LSAMP) completed Phase V with 25 years of successful LSAMP activities.  The Oklahoma Alliance, comprised of 11 institutions of higher education:  Oklahoma State University (lead institution), University of Oklahoma, University of Tulsa, Cameron University, East Central University, Langston University (HBCU), Northeastern State University, Northwestern Oklahoma State University, Southeastern Oklahoma State University, Southwestern Oklahoma State University, and the University of Central Oklahoma.  Dr. Jason F. Kirksey, Vice President for Institutional Diversity, Oklahoma State University, served as the Principal Investigator for the program. 

For over 25 years, the Oklahoma Alliance has created initiatives that significantly increased the enrollment, retention, and graduation of URMs in STEM. In Phase V, the 11-University Alliance prepared OK-LSAMP Scholars to consistently exemplify the necessary skills to be successful in globally competitive graduate programs, and in the workforce. The OK-LSAMP Program equiped our students, faculty mentors, and staff to effectively and successfully represent the exceptional nature of the program across Oklahoma, the nation, and around the world. An increasing, and transformative number of Scholars continue successfully matriculating to, and through, some of the nation?s most prestigious graduate programs. Through Phase V the Alliance supported over 650 scholars with more than 350 graduating and 92 of those graduates matriculated into graduate programs, Bridge to the Doctorate, and Graduate Fellowship programs at institutions across the United States and the world. 

 

Participants from the Oklahoma Alliance institutions took an active part in activities focused on enhancing their academic, professional and social integration.  The OK-LSAMP program proactively prepared its scholars with strategies for resilience and perseverance to successfully matriculate into graduate school, as well as future STEM careers in academia, government, or private industry.

Phase V Scholars:

  • Participated in academic year research experiences
  • Participated in summer internships
  • Participated in Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) and International Research Experiences for Undergraduates (iREU) programs
  • Were retained by over 90% as they matriculated through their STEM degree
  • Participated in professional development seminars
  • Presented research in local, national and international scientific conference and symposium presentations
  • Participated in international experiences, over 51 different international experiences, in 25 locations outside of the continental United States.
  • Received national scholarships, i.e., Goldwater, Udall, Graduate Research Fellowship, Bridge to the Doctorate, etc.
  • Research project outcomes accepted for publication in peer-reviewed journals, with scholars being lead authors
  • Maintained an average GPA of over 3.0
  • Prepared for graduate school through participation in the Preparing for Higher Degrees (PHD) Camp and other graduate success seminars

Nine of the eleven Alliance institutions continue to be ranked in the "Top 100 Degree Producers 2019 of Native American Baccalaureate - All Disciplines Combined.", according to Diverse Issues in Higher Education. Of the nine, six universities ranked within the top 16 in the nation. with Northeastern State University and Oklahoma State University consistently in the top two positions. For the ninth consecutive year Oklahoma State University received the Higher Education Excellence in Diversity Award (HEED), acknowledging the dedication to diversity and commitment to excellence.  The HEED award is presented by Insight Into Diversity magazine.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2020
Modified by: Jason F Kirksey

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Oklahoma Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (OK-LSAMP) completed Phase V with 25 years of successful LSAMP activities. The Oklahoma Alliance, comprised of 11 institutions of higher education: Oklahoma State University (lead institution), University of Oklahoma, University of Tulsa, Cameron University, East Central University, Langston University (HBCU), Northeastern State University, Northwestern Oklahoma State University, Southeastern Oklahoma State University, Southwestern Oklahoma State University, and the University of Central Oklahoma. Dr. Jason F. Kirksey, Vice President for Institutional Diversity, Oklahoma State University, served as the Principal Investigator for the program. For over 25 years, the Oklahoma Alliance has created initiatives that significantly increased the enrollment, retention, and graduation of URMs in STEM. In Phase V, the 11-University Alliance prepared OK-LSAMP Scholars to consistently exemplify the necessary skills to be successful in globally competitive graduate programs, and in the workforce. The OK-LSAMP Program equiped our students, faculty mentors, and staff to effectively and successfully represent the exceptional nature of the program across Oklahoma, the nation, and around the world. An increasing, and transformative number of Scholars continue successfully matriculating to, and through, some of the nation?s most prestigious graduate programs. Through Phase V the Alliance supported over 650 scholars with more than 350 graduating and 92 of those graduates matriculated into graduate programs, Bridge to the Doctorate, and Graduate Fellowship programs at institutions across the United States and the world. Participants from the Oklahoma Alliance institutions took an active part in activities focused on enhancing their academic, professional and social integration. The OK-LSAMP program proactively prepared its scholars with strategies for resilience and perseverance to successfully matriculate into graduate school, as well as future STEM careers in academia, government, or private industry. Received national scholarships, i.e., Goldwater, Udall, Graduate Research Fellowship, Bridge to the Doctorate, etc. Research project outcomes accepted for publication in peer-reviewed journals, with scholars being lead authors Maintained an average GPA of over 3.0 Prepared for graduate school through participation in the Preparing for Higher Degrees (PHD) Camp and other graduate success seminars Nine of the eleven Alliance institutions continue to be ranked in the "Top 100 Degree Producers 2019 of Native American Baccalaureate - All Disciplines Combined.", according to Diverse Issues in Higher Education. Of the nine, six universities ranked within the top 16 in the nation. with Northeastern State University and Oklahoma State University consistently in the top two positions. For the ninth consecutive year Oklahoma State University received the Higher Education Excellence in Diversity Award (HEED), acknowledging the dedication to diversity and commitment to excellence.
